conclusion: We have an acceleration-time graph for an elevator.
The elevator starts from rest at t=0.
We need to find the speed of the elevator at t=60s.
From t=0 to t=1s: Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s².
From t=1s to t=4s: Constant acceleration of 2 m/s².
From t=4s to t=5s: Acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0.
From t=5s to t=55s: Zero acceleration (constant velocity).
From t=55s to t=56s: Acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s².
From t=56s to t=59s: Constant acceleration of -2 m/s².
From t=59s to t=60s: Acceleration increases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0.

premise: Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s² from t=0 to t=1s.
Constant acceleration of 2 m/s² from t=1s to t=4s.
Acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 from t=4s to t=5s.
Zero acceleration from t=5s to t=55s.
Acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s² from t=55s to t=56s.
Constant acceleration of -2 m/s² from t=56s to t=59s.
